abstract.text: An object that establishes user authorization and records data for a particular sensor.

inlineContent.text: To acquire data from a particular sensor using a reader, an app creates an instance of this class using
and passes in one sensor from the available options in
A reader is a data stream for a particular sensor that the user must authorize before use. When an app calls
, the OS prompts the user for approval to use the particular sensor and determines the app’s authorization according to the user’s answer. The framework notifies the delegate with the
callback if the authorization status changes as a result of the
call. When a reader’s
is
, an app starts collecting sensor data by beginning recording.
When an app calls

, the framework starts the reader’s sensor if it isn’t already running because of a request from another app or a system process. An app has access to 7 days of prior recorded data for an active sensor. When an app calls
, the app relinquishes stakeholdership in the sensor. When a sensor has no app or system stakeholders, the framework deactivates the sensor and, thereby, stops recording data.
To fetch a sensor’s data, pass a request object to the
function.
specifies a time range that defines the age of the data, and a device, such as a phone or a watch, from which to collect the data. Use
to list the available devices, and use the time convenience-functions in Defining the Time Range to specify the time range.
If the fetch query succeeds, the framework notifies the delegate with
. The delegate receives sensor data in the form of
samples
from
. A fetch result’s
type is different depending on the particular sensor for the reader. For a mapping of sensors to their samples, see

abstract.text: Retrieve data and derived metrics from sensors on an iPhone, or paired Apple Watch.
The states that model whether the user approves the app to read a particular sensor.
User has granted authorization to this application
A representation of a device that provides sample data.
An object that defines the criteria for a sample query.
A recording that the sensor reader fetches.
The sensors an app can read.
An object that establishes user authorization and records data for a particular sensor.
The status of the user’s agreement to let the app access this reader’s sensor.
An object that responds to sensor-related events.
Fetches the samples that a fetch request specifies.
Acquires device information for all devices that store data for this reader’s sensor.
Initializes a new sensor reader object.
Requests user permission to read one or more sensors.
The particular sensor that this object reads.
Starts recording sensor data.
Stops recording sensor data.
A set of callbacks the framework invokes to notify the app of sensor-related events.
Notifies the delegate of the reader’s new authorization status.
Provides the delegate with a completed fetch request.
Provides the delegate with a fetch result.
Add metadata to your app to attain system and user permission to access sensor data.

doc://com.apple.sensorkit/documentation/.title: Configuring your project for sensor reading

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
